title: 108_hr3720
content: The Act may be cited as the "Empowering Parents and Teachers for a Drug-Free Education Act of 2004". The Congress finds that a significant percentage of high school seniors in 2001 had used illicit drugs and alcohol, with a notable increase in MDMA (ecstasy) use among 12th graders. This substance abuse poses risks to the health and safety of schoolchildren. Illicit drugs and alcohol pose health risks to students, impacting their ability to learn. Marijuana and ecstasy can harm brain cells, leading to disruptive behavior in the classroom. Smoking cigarettes or using drugs reduces students' desire to learn. Illicit drugs and alcohol negatively impact students' learning abilities, leading to lower grades and a higher likelihood of breaking school rules. SEC. 3. DRUG-FREE SCHOOL DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS. Amends the Safe and Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act to include Drug-Free School Demonstration Programs. The Secretary may grant funds to local educational agencies and private schools for drug-free school demonstration programs. These programs must include random drug testing of students using FDA-approved tests and analysis by certified drug-testing laboratories. The random drug testing program, approved by the College of American Pathologists, requires a review of positive test results by a medical review officer. It prohibits disclosure to law enforcement officials and mandates strict confidentiality of drug-testing records. Records must be destroyed if a positive test result is not confirmed, and all records must be destroyed when a student graduates or leaves the school. The random drug-testing program ensures detailed information for parents, allows them to opt-out, and includes a clear policy prohibiting drug use at school. The drug-free school program includes drug and alcohol abuse prevention training, student access to assistance programs, and continuing education. It also ensures privacy protection for student drug test results and participation in treatment programs. The drug-free school program includes prevention training, access to assistance programs, and education. It prohibits mandatory disclosure of medical information unless a student tests positive for drugs and requires written confidentiality of test results. Technical assistance contracts can be entered into for program support. Applications for grants must be submitted to the Secretary by local educational agencies or private schools. The drug-free school program includes prevention training, access to assistance programs, and education. It prohibits mandatory disclosure of medical information unless a student tests positive for drugs. A medical review officer must review drug test results. The term 'student' refers to individuals in grades 8 through 12. The Secretary of Education must submit a report to Congress on the drug-free school demonstration programs within 18 months of this Act. Authorization of $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2005 and subsequent years for these programs. Amendments made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to allocate funds for drug-free school programs. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to redesignate subpart 4 of part A of title IV as subpart 5 and insert a new section after section 4141.
